Deadpool is back! After two years of being a mercenary, he puts together a group of mutants to protect a young mutant from a time traveling mutant named Cable. This movie is hilarious, and Deadpool is not Deadpool without his pop culture references. You will be giggling the whole time. It brings the same fire from the first film. This time around, Ryan Reynolds' alter ego Deadpool has a deeper purpose than just being everybody's favorite anti-hero. It is all about family, and yes, even amidst all of the gore you will witness while watching this. I actually was not fond of how the beginning was executed. It all made sense, but it was not necessary to show it that way. The filmmakers managed to fit a lot into the film. They included not one, but possibly three villains. Cable is the most notable one, but he got his redemption at the end. Every great film has a great villain. With the element of family incorporated into the story, Cable is motivated by his family's death to stop Russell Collins from making his first kill, and his reason being that if Russell was to kill now, he will do more damage in the future. His heart is in the right place, but his solution to the problem is not, which obviously makes him the bad guy. I am satisfied with Josh Brolin's portrayal of Cable, but Cable's turnaround is very abrupt. In fact, the film gets in touch with more emotions than you would expect. At times, it did not feel natural as to how sappy it became. From start to finish, Deadpool 2 is packed with nicely choreographed action scenes. The movie very well integrates itself into real life but loses its touch once the scene features too much CGI. Overall, Deadpool 2 returns with better jokes, more blood, and an abundant amount of emotion that are added onto its action-packed story.

'Superhero fatigue' is less of a thing than 'Superhero fatigue fatigue,' based on this summer's box office numbers. The genre isn't going away any time soon. I have a large appetite for the stuff, so I hope this 'golden age' lasts for a long time. The closest I've come to that 'superhero fatigue' feeling came when I exited 'Avengers: Age of Ultron.' "That was fine," I remember saying. "It just seemed like an arc of a monthly superhero comic." A good arc (that film holds up well) but just another chapter in a big-budget soap opera.

Deadpool 2 felt like a story arc of a monthly superhero book. This time, I mean that in the best sense possible. You see, the insane, whiplash-inducing tone of this picture is deeply rooted in the Deadpool source material. Those books aren't - and can't be - as explicit in their humor, but there is a ribald streak there, along with the fourth-wall-breaking, the time travel, the ultra-violence. This film strikes that tone just as well as it's predecessor. The fun part, for me, was to see that sensibility clash more fully with the larger X-Men universe, replete with it's melodramatic fists-to-heaven pathos. Honestly, the boilerplate tearjerker beats do manage to jerk tears. This movie is a super-hero confection, for sure - but it's one of those 'mega super sour  i-dare-you-to-suck-on-it' jawbreakers.

The laughs and the action ought to satisfy general audiences (NOT children - come ON, people at my screening. HARD R.) - but the extra layer of love I feel for this thing might be due to my affinity for the X-Men lore. That's not a bad thing - I'm just saying that your mileage may vary.

Last night the Nelnie and I took in the latest superhero film that isn't Avengers related, Deadpool 2. Being big fans of the first film we were anxiously awaiting the inevitable sequel to drop after two long years. In between that time such films as Wonder Woman and Logan have dropped. So has Black Panther, which is another film I can't understand the hype of. Logan and Wonder Woman were entertaining, Black Panther was just long and confusing. 
Deadpool 2 combines some of those elements.

If you've seen Deadpool 1, don't go into this film expecting to see anything groundbreaking. This is a retread just with a different bad guy. 

Spoilers: Deadpool 2 picks up some time after the first film with the Merc With a Mouth going international, shinging his way across the globe. Then he comes home to Vanessa who has an incredibly short part in this film, although the reason for that is a big plot point. 
So Deadpool gets arrested for trying to save some kid and is taken to a mantha torture center for mutants. He and the kid are locked up, but unknown to them, Cable (Josh Brolin) is out to kill the kid. Ballwarz and teabagging ensue and the plot moves forward...

Here are some things I took away from this film in comparison to the first one.
Deadpool 1 was a lot funnier. The jokes came in almost every scene. For #2, the film's tone has shifted considerably to more of a drama with moments (not enough) of comedy sprinkled through. I wonder, had Tim Miller stayed on as director, if this would have been closer to the first film.
Deadpool 2 is a lot busier character wise. There are still the staples from Colossus and Negasonic Teenage Warhead but there's also now Cable, Domino, and a assorted others who round out the cast. Blind Al and the bartender guy are back although neither are as funny as they were.
Deadpool 2 feels longer. Wah might look at her watch during this film if she ever sees it in the theater. It isn't necessarily slow, just longer.
Deadpool 2 doesn't feel as fresh as the first film, nor is it anywhere near as funny as I already mentioned.
I kind of felt like this was forced, as if they were trying way too hard. Maybe Deadpool should have remained a one off film. However, with the box office take of the sequel, I'm pretty sure we're going to see Deadpool 3. As of this writing, the film surpassed Avengers: Infinity Ballwarz but it hasn't overtaken Passion of The Mantha Torture Center like the film mentions it wants to. I'm sure it will with overseas markets. With Hands So-Low coming out next week, I expect these two to go head to head (and butt to butt). 

Like the beginning credits said, I didn't expect nor necessarily care for the huge event that happens within the first five minutes. Granted that event is fixed by an end credit sequence (spoiler), but I still think they could have gone with a better story. Josh Brolin did good but he's not much of a comedy actor and that shows, although I think that had more to do with character than anything else. 
Would I own it? Probably, simply because the first film was so much fun.
Would I watch it regularly? Probably not as much.
Would my wife still fall asleep during it and snore? Yes she would.

Deadpool 2 gets 3 stars out of 5. It's entertaining but does not come anywhere near the first film in terms of quality and comedy. Ryan can do better. I do admit the end credits are funny, and the film has its moments, just... as I said before, not enough.

A shell of a story without any real characters or reasoning. The humor is serving itself, but never the narrative. Who are Cable, Domino, Juggernaut, or hell, any of the X-men as people? No idea. Not a single moment of real heart or characterization for them the entire movie. Hell, even Russell is just a bad copy cat of his character from Hunt for the Wilderpeople, but without any depth or heart. I never know why to care for any of it. Why is killing a kid off the limits, but murdering everyone else without questioning their level of evil ok? Or letting his X-Force die as a gag? No idea. If the kid was tortured his whole life but escaped at 19, would it then be ok to kill him? If Deadpool can go to heaven and remember it, what does that mean for the world at large? Does his death scene matter if we've already seen him die and go to heaven three times? This movie tells you right off the bat it doesn't care so you shouldn't, so have a good time...but the reason the first one worked is that it was a solid story on top of real characters WITH all the humor and meta commentary. This is just all the latter, with nothing else.

I loved the first Deadpool and for the most part Deadpool 2 is every bit as good or frequently better. Deadpool is the best example of a good divergence from source. Wade is the role that Ryan Reynolds was born to play and I would be thrilled to see him doing it for another 10 years.

When considering 'Deadpool 2,' there hasn't been another superhero sequel as good if not better than the original since Christopher Nolan flexed his muscles in the genre with 'The Dark Knight.'

The main body of 'Deadpool 2' blends together the action, plot and soundtrack to such a high degree that it's virtually unparalleled compared to other films.  From recent memory, the only other film that comes close-besides the first Deadpool-was last year's 'Baby Driver.'

The film's dialogue is packed with movie references, nods at pop culture, and even jokes at Ryan Reynold's own expense, so much so that a second viewing would absolutely be necessary to try and catch them all.

The movie isn't perfect.  For example, the first half of Cable's storyline feels a bit disjointed from the rest of the film.  However, it steadily becomes increasingly well integrated over time.

However, for a franchise that prides itself on violent irreverence, it'd be unthinkable to assume that they were capable of making audiences well up with emotion at the end, yet they had the entire theater choking back tears, a rare achievement that strongly rounds out this film and places amongst the best in its class.

DEADPOOL 2-2018(R)-May 19. By:Clem The Movie Guy. Ryan Reynolds returns as your lovable, wisecracking foul-mouthed, superhero in Deadpool 2. Since becoming Deadpool two year ago, Wade Wilson (Reynolds) has been an international mercenary taking out the worse criminals in the world. After letting a bad guy get away, Wade is heartbroken when the love of his life Vanessa (Morena Baccarin) is killed. Feeling that he just can’t live without her, Wade tries to kill himself, which is, of course, unsuccessful because of his mutant power of self-healing. At the X-Men mansion where he is recovering after Colossus literally picked up the pieces, Wade reluctantly tells Colossus (voiced of Stefan Kapičić) & Negasonic Teenage Warhead (Brianna Hildebrand) that he will try joining the X-Men. The trio is called upon to respond to a standoff situation between authorities & a troubled young mutant named Russell Collins/Firefist (Hunt for the Wilderpeople’s Julian Dennison). When Wade learns that Russell has been abused by the staffers at the Mutant Reeducation Center, he kills one of the staff members which unfortunately has him & Russell arrested & disabled with collars that disarm their powers. They are sent to an isolated mutant prison known as the “Icebox.” Wade & Russell soon encounter a soldier from the future named Cable (Josh Brolin) who has traveled back in time to eliminate Collins preventing him from becoming a blood-thirsty killer. After having a vision of Vanessa who tells him that he needs to help the troubled boy, Wade forms a team of mutants known as X-Force: Domino (Zazie Beetz), Vanisher (Brad Pitt), Bedlam (Terry Crews), Zeitgeist (IT’s Bill Skarsgård) to name a few, to save Russell from being killed by Cable. Directed David Leitch from a screenplay written by Ryan Reynolds, Rhett Reese & Paul Werhick, Deadpool 2 is outrageously entertaining with amazing action scenes & twisted humor that had me laughing throughout the film. This is just me, but I actually thought that Deadpool 2 was better than the original film, which was great. Deadpool 2 also features Shioli Kutsuna as Yukio, Negasonic Teenage Warhead's girlfriend, she joins returning cast members T.J. Miller as Weasel, Leslie Uggams as Blind Al & Karan Soni as Dopinder the cab driver. The performances from the cast were excellent, full of heart & emotion. There are several very funny scenes during the end credits so be sure to stay for those. There is so much going on in Deadpool 2 that you will have to see it again to catch the little nuggets that you missed the first time. Deadpool 2 is a MUST-SEE FILM of the summer.

This is a very hard film to review, on one hand it's one of the funniest movies of 2018 but it still follows the common sequel mould. The film is at its funniest when the jokes aren't repeated or carried on from the previous film. The best part of this film is the arc of the characters which was the weakest part of the first film. The usual issue with sequels is the tired attempt to recapture the lightening of the first by recycling jokes and Deadpool is no exception. The best part of the film is the X force team launching into action, one of the funniest segments created. The new characters breathe life into a franchise that didn't necessarily require it, but it will ensure the future of the franchise has direction. I'm reserving my complete judgement until the DVD release but this franchise is still going strong and is definitely a bold and bright choice by the filmmakers, hopefully Disney don't ruin this character. 19/05/2018.

This may have been the oddest sequel I've ever seen. Deadpool 1 was a fantastic cinema film, complete with action, interesting if not cliche plot, and best of all ONE LINERS!

But the sequel is a rollercoaster... In the best of ways! One moment you are laughing your ass off, the next you are crying, the next you have a giant cheesy grin on your face from some fan service or stupid joke.
It's weird though. I absolutely loved this movie, but it's not for everyone I fear. It's literally like a Deadpool comic jumped onto the screen. The amount of love for the character and world is astounding, but I worry this might alienate some viewers that were drawn in by the more by-the-books initial film.
Regardless, I need more Deadpool in my life. Either in film or marketing, Reynolds better keep delivering the goods!

Après le carton de sa première aventure, l'anti-héros délirant Marvel est de retour dans Deadpool 2, un film très attendu pour les nombreux fans de la franchise. Nous l'avons vu, on vous donne notre avis... sans spoil.

Il avait fait sensation en 2016, Wade Wilson est de retour cette année chargé à bloc dans un nouvel opus de la franchise Deadpool. Le casting au complet remet le couvert en y intégrant de petits nouveaux comme Zazie Beetz dans le rôle de la chanceuse Domino, Terry Crews en Bedlam, Julian Dennison est Russell, Shioli « Bisou Yukio ! » Kutsuna, Josh « Thanos » Brolin et... Peter. On notera des caméos délirants tout au long du film dont un certain Phantom, mais on ne vous en dira pas plus.

Dans les grandes lignes, l'histoire nous fait suivre Wade contraint de protéger un adolescent geignard « XXL, comme il est dit » qui est prit pour cible par Cable, un mystérieux homme venu du futur. Deadpool y versera beaucoup de sang et de membres dans des scènes d'actions toniques et parfois très gores.

Côté action justement, les amateurs de boum boum et de chorégraphies en auront largement pour leur argent avec de magnifiques combats et un budget revu à la hausse. Budget qui manque par contre au niveau des effets visuels de certains personnages entièrement fait en CGI.

Égal à lui-même, Deadpool s'en prend à toutes les firmes de comics que ce soit Marvel ou DC Comics, mais également à son interprète principal. Batman, Wolverine, Green Lantern et les X-Men en prennent plein la figure avec un Wade Wilson en pleine forme.

Pour conclure, Deadpool 2 est bien le film que l'on attendait avec son humour décapant. Les caméos sont hilarants, tout comme les personnages secondes qui malheureusement n'ont que très peu de réplique. On regrettera que certains personnages principaux n'apparaissent pas plus à l'écran comme Negasonic Teenage Warhead et Yukio (Bisou Yukio !) qui ont un gros potentiel en espérant les voir de retour dans le film X-Force. Ce second film met donc les bouchées doubles mais ne fait pas dans le « too much » car il explore suffisamment les personnages de Cable et Wade Wilson pour équilibrer entre les sérieux et les blagues potaches de notre ami en rouge et noir. Bref, un excellent opus qui ravira les fans du premier film mais aussi les lecteurs du comics.
Best movie I've seen to date

After watching this film I can say two things, Ryan Reynolds was born to play this role and R-rated superhero films are absolutely kick-ass. 'Deadpool 2', much like the first, knows exactly what type of film it's trying to be and absolutely owns it. It's quite definite now that the first installment was not a fluke and I am already eager to see Reynolds back on screen as Deadpool again. The film opens with a moment that was very surprising and took me well off guard. This is a spoiler free review but I will say that what happens early on in the film offers our hero a new challenge on many different levels. That's what sequels are all about, giving the main character challenges greater than in the first, and the writers did that perfectly. I will say when I found out director Tim Miller was not returning to direct this sequel I was nervous for where it would go and if the tone would stay the same. When I discovered David Leitch (director of 'John Wick' and 'V for Vendetta') was set to helm the sequel my worries disappeared, and rightfully so. Leitch completely embraces the tone from the first film and did an incredible job directing this movie. He did such a good job that I hope to see him back at the helm of another potential 'Deadpool' film down the road. 
The film is flat-out hilarious, one of the reasons the first movie was so much fun was because of its sheer dark comedy and that was back in full force in the sequel. 'Deadpool 2' was extremely funny and it made for yet another fun time at the movies. Keep in mind, not all the one liners in this movie land perfectly and that is expected in a film like this, but overall there is not much of a gripe regarding that. 'Deadpool 2' is able to do something that it didn't do in the first - a balance of heart and comedic tone. Let's face it, these films thrive when it's time for some comedy but this film was able to adapt a more serious, emotionally touching tone than the first and it brought Reynolds' character, 'Wade Wilson', down to earth a little. 


The rest of the cast in the movie did an incredibly good job. Josh Brolin as 'Cable' was bad-ass to see on screen. It felt like it took a little while for Brolin to actually start kicking ass in this film but whenever he is on screen, he is quite entertaining. I felt as if the movie should've explored 'Cable' a little more but as the movie progresses you do learn more about this character and it was fulfilling in that way. Zazie Beetz as 'Domino' in this film was rather good and she provides some good action sequences as well as some subtle wit. 'Colossus' and 'Negasonic' are both great in this movie as their characters continued from the first movie, but I wished they explored these characters a little more. I personally found Julian Dennison who plays 'Russell Collins/Firefist' to be the one clear weak spot in this film acting-wise. His role in the film is rather important as he pieces together the big challenge that Reynolds must face but I did not like their chemistry nor did I enjoy his isolated moments in the movie. 
'Deadpool 2' got a huge increase in budget from the first film so this movie was clearly a much more extravagant and CGI centered film but there were times when two CGI characters went head to head that I did not fully buy into the special effects being used and I won't go as far to say that it took me out of the film, but it was a notable weakness. The rest of the action sequences in this film are awesome. Much like the first movie, there is gore... and a lot of it. The fight scenes in this movie with Brolin and Reynolds are ridiculously awesome and quite a lot of fun to watch.

I'll start off and be completely honest in saying that I thoroughly enjoyed the first Deadpool film, but wasn't blown away or busting a gut laughing from start to finish. The meta jokes were fantastic and the story itself was even quite engaging, but it wore thin for me by the third act. That being said, I found myself hoping that a sequel would be even better. Deadpool 2 has just hit the big screen, and while I can't say it's a funnier movie, I can say the film itself is a vast improvement when looking at the filmmaking alone. This movie does a good job of creating new jokes and even making old jokes funny again, but there's something about these movies that has me having a hard time falling in love with them. Here's why Deadpool 2 comes highly recommended for fans, but not at all for anyone else.

Quite a few plot devices are used here, but without getting to any spoilers, Deadpool 2 follows Wade Wilson once again, as he feels the need to protect a young boy with superpowers, while a time-traveling mutant in Cable is one the rise, hunting this boy down. From realizing that he may just work better with partners, to realizing that he may love more than just himself, there are a lot of storylines and emotional aspects that elevate this from another average superhero comedy. I found myself shocked to see how much time was spent on action or drama, instead of the need to always joke around. Yes, this movie is riddled with humor from start to finish, but this felt like a more mature version of the previous film.

As far as the humor itself goes, I mentioned that I quite enjoyed what they did with the first movie, but felt that it wore out by the end. This time around, the jokes felt a little more spread out, which is why I believe they worked better here, so I could catch a breath and not be hounded with excessive amounts of comedy. You may actually feel differently about that because there are jokes throughout certain dramatic moments, but I chose to see it as a dramatic moment, rather than a comedic one. So I was pleasantly surprised to see a nice blend of those two genres.

Ryan Reynolds continues to prove that he was born to play this role. Not many actors/actresses can prove that they were meant to act in a specific role, but Reynolds is definitely one of the few who can. It goes without saying that his heart is in these movies until the very end, so how was the supporting cast? Josh Brolin delivers a solid performance as Cable, but I feel as though he comes out of nowhere during the beginning of the movie. I felt a little short-changed in terms of his development. His screen time vastly increases by the end and made his character worth it, but I still wished to see a little more from him.

Everyone has been seeing images and footage in the trailers for the tease at the X-Force team that Deadpool recruits here, and I can say that their screen time is easily one of the highlights of the entire film. Looking back on the movie, the character of Domino (played by Zazie Beetz) is easily my favorite in the entire film. Her ability is hilarious and very unique in combat, and each of these characters just added another level to the movie, whether they were shining in an action sequence, or just there to make the audience laugh, or leave them shocked.

In the end, I enjoyed this sequel just as much as its predecessor. I thought the first movie lacked a tone that this one presented, but the comedy will impress viewers more in the first film, so there is a balance that really has me debating which one I liked more. Deadpool 2 benefits from very solid direction from David Leitch and the fact that Ryan Reynolds joined writers Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick made it feel a little different from the first. The first movie was a celebration that a movie like this could be made, but this one dives a little deeper and I quite enjoyed that about it. While I don't love either of these movies, they are a blast to watch. Deadpool 2 has its issues, but it's a solid movie all around.

Hilarious yet heart felt sequel that quite frankly surpasses the original on every level.  Ryan Reynolds continues his brilliant turn as Deadpool, delivering one-liners faster than a machine gun while giving a real warmth & character arc to him (he really isn't lying when he says this film is about family).  The cast is nicely fleshed out as well, with Josh Brolin nicely menacing as Cable while Zazi Beetz is fun as Domino.  Behind the camera, director David Leitch uses his action movie prowess to great affect, delivering some brilliantly choreographed set pieces that, like his 'John Wick' films, rely on longer takes and a pulled back camera.  The film is also filled with numerous cameos and fourth-wall breaks that will require multiple viewings to catch them all, along with one of the best post-credit scenes to date.  Most importantly, despite all the gory action & humor, there is a genuine heart to the film that gives Deadpool a real heroes journey.  Simply put, a film that not surpasses it's sequel, thus being one of the best comic book movies ever made.

Fantastic movie. After going in with admittedly mixed expectations given the super high bar the first set, this film exceeded all of them to deliver a sequel on an absolutely equal level as its predecessor. Combining richer character development seen in recent Marvel hits Black Panther and Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 and doubling down on what made the first such a hit as John Wick Chapter 2 did, this film is an exhilarating, hilarious, meta-fueled, drenched in gore feast that entertains from start to finish, where even the jokes that don’t land safely at least conjure a chuckle, and the action and special effects are bigger and work for the film, the introduction of new characters work well for the majority and the performances are fantastic, especially Reynolds, Beetz, Brolin and Soni.

 a new baddie named Cable played by Josh Brolin comes in serving a Terminator-esque plot by going back in time to prevent a terrible future from happening
 Colossus still wants to recruit Wade to join the X-Men but of course he has zero interest
 his love interest Vanessa says at one point kids help us be better at who we are; when a child mutant at a rehab center goes crazy with revenge it might be Wade's chance to help another lost soul
 Cable is hot on his trail though and Wade puts together his own team called the X-Force consisting of Domino, Shatterstar, and even a plain guy named Pete
 the jokes in here are so over-the-top and crazy to say the least but that's what makes this follow-up so much damn fun
 next to Deadpool's spot-on foul mouth, bloody violent antics, and inside references the movie packs more of a fun punch this time
 with a bit of heart to go along with the senseless violence and crass funny bits Ryan Reynolds and director David Leitch continue to increase the appeal of this merc-with-the mouth
 sure he's immature and has a lot to learn but the important idea of family and teamwork goes a long way
 there's never a dull moment and it's non-stop laughs throughout
 make sure to watch the mid-credits scene as well because it'll knock your socks off just how far they go, it's such a riot! :)
 Deadpool's still got it where it counts

I agree with people that the first movie was a bit too long and most jokes we're good and some were mediocre and at very bad moments but this second movie made me happy for it's running time as it is a one hour and fifty-five minute movie which is a perfect running time for a movie that depends on it's jokes and humor which is the reason why I watched this movie, I didn't watch it for it's story or anything I just watched it for it's impressively good humor and to me this movie is a step up from the first movie and has its huge moments with the humor and isn't afraid to be it's own movie. I wonder what marvel and 21st century has next in store for this franchise. Deadpool 2 will forever be one of my favorite movies.

BETTER THAN THE FIRST !!!!

If all you want from Deadpool 2 is everything from Deadpool 1, then I regret to inform you that you won't be getting what you ask for... 

And that is a damn good thing!

Every bit of the comedic genius of Deadpool 2's predecessor sparks that primal bellow of laughter none of us humans know how to resist. You know, like when you were a kid and something silly made you giggle in to a fit of uncontrollable laughter. That is the caliber of comedy this movie has in spades, diamonds, clubs, and.... hearts.

Which brings me to the next thing I loved about this film. It breaks it's own mold, the one set by the original. Not only is it a brilliant superhero comedy-action film, but it also has evolved to included drama among it's genres. This movie makes you care about Wade Wilson not as a comic book character come to life, but as a person. Deadpool 2 successfully humanizes is anti-protagonist in an evolution unique unto itself. And that is not even the last OR best thing this movie has added to it's already bursting roster of value.

The last thing I'll write about here is the one that, in Marvel meta terms, is bar none the most significant thing this movie does;

It fixes the problem of how does Marvel introduce The X-Men in to it's MCU while also having possibly just introduced (and in no way did many people see this coming) Lady Death. Let that settle for a minute as you imagine what that could mean for part two of Infinity War... and then I'll continue below.

Listen, Deadpool 2 broke all expectations I had of it. I wasn't even sure it'd be a good movie after the original's writer left. But instead, and right now, there is a multifaceted movie that has everything a good movie should have in it. 

Does every bit of it with near-perfect execution. Do a few jokes miss their landing? Depends on who's watching. Was the humanization of the titular anti-hero unwarranted and the one comedically unbroken scene of real human drama not earned? Depends on who's watching (in 2018 - before Infinity War 2 - and possibly so many more Phase 4-5 movies!).  Was it disappointing to watch Shatterstar's body brutally destroyed? Nope. Not with who the real X-Force becomes by the end. And that kind of misdirection from a pre-release marketing standpoint is brilliant. As are many things this movie does.

So please, go throw your money at Deadpool 2. Now.

Deadpool 2 delivers the same action and comedy of the original, but on a bigger scale. The jokes and pop culture references are all aimed for the 21 to 45 crowd and I was surprised at the amount of cross over "name dropping" from other comics. With a bigger budget, expect a lot of better action scenes and CGI. Believe it or not, the main story actually has a nice message too. Josh Brolin is great as Cable but I gotta say Zazie Beetz as Domino steals the show here, she was amazing. It goes to show that a strong empowered super woman doesn't always have to be extremely tomboy, a bitch, pessimistic, or have a jaded past. Funny, sarcastic, and nice can still be part of a badass superheroine. Stay for the end credits, they are glorious! But don't stay for the after credits, there is nothing, you've been warned. Final Review 9 out of 10.

Deadpool 2 is a little more cheeky than the last, and in my opinion that's a good thing. I had a lot of good laughs, smiles, and found myself much more drawn in than the first. The story picked up speed and kept running with it. Would recommend to any fans of Deadpool or action comedies who don't mind a bit of a raunchy twist.
One of my favorite movies.

Uses the same comedy as the previous film with lots of wit, but it becomes a bit obnoxious as almost the whole film can essentially be boiled down to just repetitive self-deprecating Marvel references and ultra-violent deaths played off as comedy, interspersed with same-y fight scenes. A bit too much for me, but if you enjoyed the first film you'll most likely find it a worthwhile watch.

Deadpool 2 succeeds where so many sequels fail. Rather than just attempting to skate by on the success of the first film, Deadpool 2 instead delivers a grittier, more heartfelt film that still manages all the hilarity of the first. The film does an excellent job of expanding the Deadpool universe, having an interesting plot and characters you'll actually care about, and being funny, all while staying true to the spirit that made the first film such a success. One thing to note, and slight SPOILER, but make sure to stay for the end credit scenes. Trust me, they're important.

Don't get me wrong - 'Deadpool 2' is a damn good time at the movies. It just isn't as refreshingly wonderful as the original film, which I think took us all genuinely by surprise. 
This sequel is full of laugh out loud moments (and even a few genuinely emotional ones) but there are long stretches where it feels a bit like its treading water. 
Forever kudos though to Ryan Reynolds and Co. for not holding ANYTHING back when it comes to bringing this wild character to the big screen. Their embrace of every aspect of the character is insanely brave and makes the film well worth our time and money even if it isn't the greatest comic book film of the year.

This is the funniest movie I have seen in years. Never has a studio been so willing to see itself lampooned on the big screen by its own product. From the first minute to the last Ryan Renolds sometimes as Deadpool sometimes as himself is merciless in his take on all things superhero; especially Marvel Studios. He does take some swipes at DC and other sources but the butt licking he gives Marvel is refreshing especially after the gut wrenching ending of Infinity Wars.To many spoilers to go into detail and frankly no need. The rapid-fire humor of this politically incorrect, sometimes-tasteless but always funny offering will leave you in stitches from start to finish, with its scathing one-liners and clever-as-all-get-out sight gags. While there's a slight tendency to include too many current cultural references that won't stand the test of time, the film nevertheless delivers the goods when it needs to. Infinity what?

That said there were some good fourth wall breaks and floppy DeadPool gags that I laughed at. Domino was one of many surprise favorites, she lived up to and surpassed her comic counterpart. Another huge strong point for the movie was the lack of a feeling that scenes were written to set up future movies, everything felt self contained which made me actually want to see some of these characters again!
Cable, Firefist and the big guy are awesome, and task force X hilarious. But I guess if you get to the third movie of a trilogy without a potential apocalypse, you kind of earn the right to do that lol

Deadpool 2 (4 out of 5 stars). Deadpool 2 is back and turns out to live up to the first movie. With plenty of exciting action sequences, a wise cracking script and performance from Ryan Reynolds that delivers with lots of humor. Ryan Reynolds is born to play the character. Plus the humor in the movie does take a lot of jabs to the Marvel characters from The Avengers or making fun of DC for its seriousness. It may not be the best superhero movie with a thin plot or lacking depth with the villain (I will avoid spoilers on the plot). Is it better than the first film? I will say they are equally entertaining. The first movie did not have much depth with the plot either. The plot follows Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) after a downhill spiral on life. He may be given another chance to do a good deed by saving a moody mutant teen Russell (Julian Dennison) who has the powers of firefist. When Cable (Josh Brolin) arrives from the future and his only goal is to kill Russell. Deadpool enlists new recruits to form a team called X Force with one of the members being Domino (Zazie Beetz). I will say the plot felt a little thin when it comes to having a story. Has that Terminator concept with a man coming from the future to rewrite history. Sure, there is a joke thrown in there from that concept. The movie is nonetheless entertaining, funny, and exciting. There are plenty of action sequences that keep the pace moving. The opening montage of Deadpool facing against criminal mobs internationally to an opening credit scene that feels like a James Bond movie with a song played by Celine Dion (which works with the setting and tone of the opening scene). The car chase scene with the huge armored prisoner transport vehicle and Domino and Deadpool facing against Cable was the highlight of the movie. I felt like the climax of the movie was a little bit short. Without giving away spoilers, the turning point of the villain was a bit weak. Also, you get to know a little about Cable and his motives on going after Russell. Josh Brolin was perfect as Cable. It would be difficult to see anyone else playing the character. Morena Baccarin returns. Same with T.J. Miller the wise cracking buddy of Deadpool. Colossus returns as the goody good X-Men character that is trying to recruit Deadpool to doing good. Brianna Hildebrand is back as Negasonic Warhead but with a short role. Zazie Beetz is Domino. And her character is also the highlight of the movie. She did great with the role. I did not like Julian Dennison as Russell. A character that is moody with anger issues and undeveloped. It was difficult to care for the character even when Deadpool and Domino are trying to save him. The movie had plenty of humor. It did not take itself seriously which threw jokes towards Marvel's characters, DC, even the I want to build a snowman from Frozen. The humor was fun and stupid. Overall, Deadpool 2 is a good superhero film. Ryan Reynold's delivered with performance and script. He is the wise cracking character, which also poked fun at himself. The action was exciting and also delivered by a director David Leitch (who did movies like John Wick and Atomic Blonde). Josh Brolin and Zazie Beetz were great and highlights of the movie. The film is a lot of fun with plenty of humor and action. Also, there is two mid credit scenes that is a lot of fun as it pokes fun at the character. I do recommend seeing this film in theatres if you enjoyed the first movie for the action and its raunchy stupid humor.

"It feels bigger," runs the tagline for this potty-mouthed sequel. It's a cheeky double entendre that in fact holds very true; there's a massively increased budget ($110m compared to the first's $58m), an A-list co-star (Josh Brolin) to share the publicity burden, and an extra ten minutes on the runtime. But does bigger mean better? Not quite, but it's pretty bloody close. With extra cash to throw around and a director-swap seeing ex-stunts coordinator David Leitch (Atomic Blonde) take the helm, one thing is for sure: the action set pieces are more ambitious and accomplished. The bar is set high early on, the movie opening with a stylish killing-spree montage sequence boasting both an awesome Kill Bill homage and a sensational single-take bloodbath. From there we get a hard-hitting prison breakout (with Brolin's Cable stealing the show), a bonkers melee aboard a high-speed truck, and a finale featuring some slick close quarters combat; all sprinkled with some cartoonish ultra-violence befitting of a Deadpool outing. Adding lead star Ryan Reynolds to the screenwriting team - presumably to bolster the dialogue with his trademark attitude - the subversive fourth-wall breaking and offensive humour is in full swing once again. It doesn't land with the same did-that-just-happen impact of the original because this time it's expected; but a decrease in shock value doesn't lessen the amusement of witty pop culture references (the MCU features heavily) or blink-and-they'll-vanish celebrity cameos. And of course there's Deadpool himself. The charismatic Reynolds plays the Merc with the Mouth with unbridled smart-arse glee, clearly relishing every zinger and barb he gets to unleash. The supporting cast is a mixed bag though: Brolin and Zazie Beets shine as the badass Cable and the very lucky Domino respectively, but Kiwi jokester Julian Dennison fails to ignite as tormented teen Russell and returning cast members T.J. Miller and Morena Baccarin are under-utilised. A sequel that doubles down on its tongue-in-cheek tone, over-the-top action and savage humour, Deadpool 2 is an uproarious superhero ride that offers fans more of what they love.

Personally, Deadpool is a great choice of comedy and action film, and maybe even romantic love story, this guy's still maintained his badass charm for nearly 10 years. For anyone who hasn't seen the film yet: don't believe everything you see in the trailers, it's like IW ver.2. Chimichanga!

"Deadpool 2" (R, 1:59) is a superhero action-adventure comedy, which is a sequel to 2016's boundary-shattering "Deadpool". This is the 11th of the X-Men films. Although Marvel Comics properties, neither the X-Men or Deadpool films are considered part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. This one was written by returning scribes Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick, but this time with help from franchise star Ryan Reynolds. Version 2.0 has a different director, David Leitch ("Atomic Blonde", "John Wick"), after original director Tim Miller left the project due to "mutual creative differences" with Reynolds.

Much like the original, the sequel has plenty of sarcasm, inuendo, social political satire, meta humor, 4th wall breaking... and bloody violence. Fan favorite characters are back too! The titular "merch with the mouth" remains devoted to his one true love, Vanessa (Morena Baccarin), is still friends with his former roommate, Blind Al (Leslie Uggams), and continues to receive support from his best friend, Weasel (T.J. Miller), and favorite cab driver, Dopinder (Karan Soni), while still being frenemies with X-"Men" Colossus (Stefan Kapicic) and Negasonic Teenage Warhead (Brianna Hildebrand). D2, however, has more heart, as Mr. Pool's capacity for love and self-sacrifice extend beyond his relationship with Vanessa and he begins playing nice with others... kind of. Well, some early narration does refer to this as "a family movie", so...

After a shocking tragedy early in the film (so early that the opening credits get all meta with it), Wade Wilson / Deadpool is acting darker than usual. Colossus and NTW take Wade to the X-Mansion and try to break him out of his funk by getting him involved in X-Men business. When they take him to a mutant rehab facility to try talking down an overweight mutant teen named Russell (Julian Dennison) who is threatening violence against the facility's manager (Eddie Marsan), the way Wade handles the situation drives a fresh wedge between him and the X-Men. Wade decides that Russell needs his protection (and that Wade himself needs to do some protecting), so he forms a paramilitary mutant group that he calls X-Force. This puts him, and new recruits like Domino (Zazie Beetz), Zeitgeist (Bill Skarsgård) and Bedlam (Terry Crews), up against a huge mutant called Juggernaut and a another known as Cable (Josh Brolin) who has come from the future for the sole purpose of killing Russell. Yeah, there's a lot going on here.

"Deadpool 2" would be a blockbuster if it were the first in the series, but can't quite match the original. Well how could it? 2016's "Deadpool" was a shock to the system, a real game changer. This one keeps in place the attitude and the actors which made the first one so popular and expands the title character's world to give us more to look at, but the sequel isn't as fresh and effortlessly entertaining as the original. D2 may be a little bit less slick than its predecessor, but in and of itself, it's still a damn good time. "A-"

Still incredibly funny, though... I laughed out loud several times and didn't feel guilty about it. Superhero fanatics, make sure to stay for all of the end credit scenes... you won't be disappointed. B+, 4/5, 8/10 on IMDB.

The original Deadpool had laid the groundwork of background story and hype with the cinematic theme of breaking the 4th wall, Deadpool 2 hits the ground running on that same formula, if you are looking for a good time with a few new twists, a more dark but richer laugh, and a scratch into Deadpool as a character and his development, then stay tuned, come for the laughs and stay for what could be plans for Deadpool that have yet to be realized, any fan of the original material knows that there is a lot that can be utilized there, such as Deadpool's relationship with Help, but if you need a reminder...the comics for Deadpool we're not very good.

There is a scene in the opening moments of Deadpool 2 that immediately bears weight and feels significant to the narrative arch of our anti-hero Deadpool. It was in that moment I also realized I had very little recollection of the story from the first film. My memory was more of what Deadpool was, rather than who surrounds him in his universe. 
Initially, it doesn't seem like the supporting characters should really matter that much in a film with such a colorful title star, but Deadpool 2 and Ryan Reynolds thrive in the spaces surrounding the variety of personas in the film.

Picture Deadpool taking on a challenge course. Each obstacle in the course requires a unique approach and is interacted with differently than the others. This is easier said than done in movies, but the range Reynolds shows in how his character connects with his wife Vanessa, Weasel the bartender, his eager friend Dopinder, and Russell the troubled youth is impressive. Perhaps it's my memory of what Deadpool was - a raunchy, sarcastic, silly hero - I was surprised when a range was shown that offered more to the character and built something that mattered. 

There are many lines throughout the film that want to give us the impression this movie doesn't want to be taken seriously. This includes sections where Reynolds breaks the third wall, calling out the writers for being lazy, or saying a CGI fight is upcoming. It's almost like the talented kid in high school, who might be surprisingly good at a niche, unpopular activity and then wants to downplay their own talent when others discover what they are capable of.
 
Deadpool 2 offers a memorable experience that is more than just reintroducing a wacky character, it's a journey that feels like it matters and is very worthy of your time.

Deadpool 2 delivers more of the laughs and extreme violence that made its predecessor a refreshing departure from the same old superhero genre, and with a surprising amount of heart this time around, thankfully that bull doesn't get in the way of the hilarity, gore, and gleefully profane Deadpool fun!

This was okay. It starts much better than it middles or ends. They try to go with a more serious plot but try to shove too much plot in if they're going to dwell on mediocre gags for several minutes. For a film with a lot of action, it feels really slow and dull at points. Most of the jokes don't come close to landing and there's no reason to care about any character other than Deadpool. There's a kid actor in this who I was convinced had to be related to someone or have won a contest because the acting is that bad and one-note. Nope. He's got multiple film credits somehow. The plot really needed to be streamlined because it's not clear what the actual plot is until halfway through the film. And with all that waiting, it's nothing that interesting once you get to it. It felt more like an episode of Family Guy than anything, relying on references rather than actual jokes. It's not the worst film in the world. It's just really disappointing and not terribly funny.

Although I liked the first movie a little bit more, this movie was still a blast. It is definitely funnier than the first. Be sure to stick around when the credits start for the mid-credits scene. Trust me. You don't want to miss what happens.

This movie has a better budget than the first one, which results in better action scenes and a lot more places and characters for Deadpool to interact with, which keeps things more interesting. Brolin does a good job as the straight man in Deadpool's world of insanity and kicking butt. However, it's Zazie Beets who really steals the show as Domino. She does a great job as the sassy, sarcastic counterpart to Deadpool and her luck powers work for some really creative fight scenes. No spoilers, but one X-Men character who has never gotten his or her due finally gets his/her cinematic moment to shine.

Now, why do I think the first one is better if this one is funnier? Deadpool 1 was a lot more solid plot-wise. Deadpool 2 is darker and more anarchist than the first. At times, the more serious scenes feel like they conflict with the more humorous ones. I do appreciate the need for an emotional backbone to the film, things could've been smoother. Anyway, if you liked the first you should still really like this.

DEADPOOL 2

The 1st film was like a feature length apology for the...thing that they called "Dead Pool" in 'Xmen Origins: Wolverine'. Can our merc keep his momentum? Let's find out.

At 2 hours even, IT DOESN'T MATTER HOW LONG IT WAS, 'CAUSE THIS FILM IS FLIPPIN' AWESOME!!!!!!! It's everything the first film was and more! I could not for the life of me find any flaws. In my humble opinion, it has surpassed Avengers & all it's progeny as THE greatest superhero film of the modern age!!!! But it's still not a kid's film. No nudity this time, but still way too much violence & swearing for the young'uns. Ah heck with it! Bring'em anyway! This film is too good to pass up!!!

The cast hasn't lost a step. Ryan Reynolds is going to be DeadPool for the next hundred years at least! He blends comedy & tragedy in a way that would make the ancient Greeks bow down in praise. And he's not so stuck up that he won't self depreciate. The rest of the original cast each have their moments, & none of them are wasted or forgotten. Now let's get into the new characters. Domino. Let's face it, most of us just know her as boobs fer lookin' at, but in the movie, she could hold her own in a scene, she helped the story move, & her power, while subtle, was always visible. I found her to be kind've a modern Foxy Brown, & I hope to see her in many future installments. Cable. Not quite as over the top as the cartoon I remember, but still well played, he was like this universe's Rambo, he emoted without telegraphing, you could feel his pain & see where he was comin' from. The not-villain was soooo relatable! So many of us could see ourselves going to that dark place! The true villains were cookie cutter, & it was satisfying to see their end. The rest of the cast didn't have the spotlight long, but they did leave a nice impression, including a few surprises.

The effects were golden! Practical stunts, CGI that wasn't afraid to be itself, what more can I say?

The music was just the right mix(tape) of '90s awesome. 'Nuff said.

Overall, I laughed, I cried, I wanted both sides to win in some way, & they did. It was an Oscar worthy roller coaster, it was a family film in every sense of the word, & DEADPOOL 2 IS....5 stars outta 5!
Laughed my ass off the whole time!!

Deadpool II is a refreshing addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe that just came off one of their more serious films, Infinity War, along with Black Panther which also didn't hit all of its humor notes well. For the true fan of Marvel, this is another coveted film that leaves no prisoners. DC, X-Men or Marvel in general, Deadpool II does a great job of giving its fans a great laugh throughout. Ryan Reynolds is brilliant once again and truly embodies the Deadpool character. The movie enhances some of the character roles from the first film, (ex. Dopinder) and also does a great job focusing on the main hero instead of relying heavily on the primary villain. Deadpool is easy to root for and simply an amazing to follow. Hilarious, edgy, and surprising in several ways, I highly recommend this film and anyone who doesn't understand its logic probably doesn't have the same appreciation for the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Deadpool 2 once again stars Ryan Reynolds as Wade Wilson, the Merc with the mouth and this time around he is bringing together a team known as the X-Force, to try to save a mutant kid who is in danger of being killed by the time-traveling mutant Cable played by Josh Brolin.

I'm a massive fan of the first film, I thought it was a very straight forward simple exciting hilarious comic book movie and one that a lot people didn't know they wanted or needed.

This time around the directing chair is taken by one half of the team that brought you the first John Wick movie David Leitch. He's known for crafting amazing action scenes and Deadpool 2 is filled with them; this movie is a total blast to watch regarding the action.

There is a white-knuckle chase scene in this film that rivals the highway chase that started the first film, and as per usual with the Deadpool character this movie is very, very funny. Lots of jokes, not all of them land as usual with a comedy but most of them do because this character is so endearing despite being such a loudmouth.

This truly is the year of Josh Brolin he's one of the best parts of the film, newcomers Julian Dennison and Zazie Beetz are great, as are most of the returning cast. Ryan Reynolds continues to show that the role of Deadpool was made for him, by also bring Deadpool down to earth a little bit and explores more of the character that is Wade Wilson and less of Deadpool and it makes him a more compelling character with a deeper side to him.

Deadpool 2 is a weird movie. On the one hand, it's the film you expect it to be: raunchy jokes flying at you non-stop paired with gory violence. That's the character, that's the brand, and that's why the first movie was a success. But on the other hand, buried beneath all the F-bombs and superhero references is a real story about Deadpool. He's learning to fight for someone other than himself and opening up his heart. It's the kind of storytelling that the rest of the movie would seem all-too-eager to mock. This gives Deadpool 2 a case of tonal whiplash where you're laughing hysterically at the devil-may-care jokes only to have you pump the brakes and care about Deadpool's emotional arc. And yet at the end, Deadpool 2 is similar to its predecessor in that you'll have a blast while watching it.

This was a great addition to the Deadpool movie lineup.  If you enjoyed the first one, you'll like what they're doing here, even though there are a few missteps in the dialogue, and the CGI isn't very inspired.  The opening is very James Bond-esque and I love they had Celine Dion singing it.  
I loved Domino, but was very worried about the character before viewing the movie.  I was not, however, sold on Peter.  He sucks, and is irredeemable, in my opinion.  The other characters seem fine, and there's a little cameo by Brad Pitt, as well as Matt Damon, even though you won't recognize him.  The worst part of this movie was either Colossus, and his 'That's how we do it in mother Russia" line, or Deadpool when he pops up at a funeral in the beginning, because that was terrible.
The child actor playing Fire Fist was good, and you get to see him get punched in the face a few times for good measure. 
Action was pretty consistent, and enjoyable to watch with some pretty intense gore at times, but more than the situation called for.  

Overall, just leave the kids at home (my first showing of this had two small children in the theater making quite a bit of noise near the beginning, shame on their parents)  and be ready to have some fun watching people get set of fire and chopped up.

Deadpool has a ton of laughs with gags at every turn, with so many packed in, you can easily blink and miss some. The plot is engaging and you never know where it will go. The characters continue to be fun with Ryan Reynolds being the star of the show with his great 4th wall breaking and charismatic attitude however this overshadows the rest of the movie. With so many new and old characters plus a lot of story to cover, the movie seems overfilled especially compared to the first which played it more simple. The humour and R rating also means it follows in the footsteps of other comic sequels like Kick Ass 2 which where they have to up the anti to controversial and gross out humour

Great movie. I understand and would warn that it is not going to be everybody's cup of tea. If you liked DP, you will most likely love DP2. If you didn't like DP, don't bother as it is more of the same. The movie was able to get going much more quickly as we didn't need to meet Deadpool. The attempt to wring emotion was a bit contrived both with the love interest and the new "adopted" child. This is the only area where the original was superior. 

In all other respects DP2 is amazing. The action sequences are more "realistic" at times, the new characters Domino and Cable are excellent. I don't want to malign Brolin's excellent job as Cable but Zazie Beetz as Domino was amazing. The performance was aided by some excellent cinematography showing how her luck power works. The discussion of whether luck is a power was a nice touch.

The humor was there, the fourth wall destruction was there, the raunchiness was there. A nice addition to the mansion based team of Colossus and Negasonic was Yukio, a take on the bubbly asian trope but enjoyable nonetheless. The only reason for the missing half star is the movie, in my opinion took the easy way out at the end. There was some seriousness to the film and then it just kind of wimped out. IMO making the hard choice would have been a better movie.

PS Stick around for the mid credit scene. Funniest one ever made.

Deadpool 2

A sadistic approach on the comic tone has always been its window which they have increased to an annoying amount of time as it manages to undermine the current moment. Just as the first installment, there isn't much to look forward to on the plotline (which is predictable) but the journey it takes; even though it derails a lot, is intriguing and amusing at the same time. The major conundrum of the feature would be the lack of connection with the audience (even though the protagonist is literally filling in the audience with the details) as the stakes and emotions projected in here are shallow and doesn't go as anticipated. The songs are upbeat but the technical aspects could have been a lot better like the background score, vfx and editing. David Leitch has done a decent work on directing and pulling off the mayhem that this feature is, but unfortunately wasn't supported by the cinematography or the choreography which is essential in such features. The performance isn't upto the mark by Ryan Reynolds (but then Deadpool is quite complex to play) and neither is supported to that extent by Josh Brolin which comes off a bit disappointing. Deadpool 2 is an overstretched feature that numbs the emotions as it ages on screen let along draw it out and the soul reason would be due to the wafer thin script that never bothers to even justify the actions occurring or even make a definite point out of it. Having said that, if considered as just a parody of another installment of its predecessor, it works just fine.

One minute it tries so very hard to be serious and dark and the next a raunchy comedy. The jokes are really hit or miss, though most are a hit, but when they miss the film just gets cringey. I get that most will love this film. It's not a bad film. It's just not as good as the first. The big stand outs in this film are Cable and Domino.

There's nothing quite like seeing an actor actually ENJOYING the role he's playing. That type of enthusiasm is infectious, and like most infections, takes a while to get rid of. Sometimes, you blame yourself for getting infected, or you blame society for allowing something like this to exist, but this movie is meant for the folks who don't give a damn about the consequences and just want to relax and ride bareback in a movie theat--

OK, maybe my analogy is not the best, but I think you get what I'm saying: this movie is fun. In fact, what prevents it from being the exercise in total irreverence of the expected Deadpool is the attempt to inject an unironic lesson of heroism for the Merc with a Mouth. The seriousness of this plotline (which is basically "Looper") is just tonally different to be a bit of a downer.

Of the extensive supporting cast, the standouts are (besides Reynolds) Julian Dennison as Russell and especially Zazie Beets as Domino. I am a bit disappointed we didn't see more of Brianna Hildebrand as Negasonic Teenage Warhead, who was (for me) the best scene-stealer in the first Deadpool, and the limited screentime of Morena Baccarin is felt throughout. 

Well, we'll always have X-Men Origins: Wolverine and Green Lantern to remember. Or do we?

Ryan Reynold's Wade Wilson (Deadpool) and Josh Brolin's Cable are joined by an amazing cast of characters to combat a threat unlike any other.

Friendship, Family & Love are the name of the game with this film.

This very, very, R-rated film is probably not the best choice for teens or kids but an enjoyable night out with friends or a significant other are not out of the question here!

From a purely objective point of view 'Deadpool 2' was a great film if you are interested in the odd genre it has created for itself. The franchise has become synonymous for its over the top language, violence and pointed sexual innuendos and this particular sequel to 20th Century Fox's cult hit, is no exception. If it is your desire to see a superhero film that makes you cheer for the hero and clap when the bad guy gets what he has coming to him, then I am afraid that this is not the film for you. If this is a film that you want to take your children to, may I suggest you reconsider, because this film and its predecessor are not for the eyes and ears of the innocent. 
As of right now, 'Deadpool 2' is rocking an 84% on rottentomatoes.com, but I expect that number to fluctuate as more movie critics submit their personal opinions over this film. I personally believe the current critic score for this film is spot on because of this film's genre. 'Deadpool 2' is a comedy before it is anything else, and as comedies go, this film has a ton of jokes that hit and quite a few that missed. At times the quick little quips were funnier than the long running jokes that appeared with greater frequency as the film progressed, something that Deadpool himself attributed to lazy writing, along with certain plot points. If your intention was to see a film about a super hero, I say again, this is the wrong film for you. 
With a runtime of nearly two hours this film is not just vulgar joke after vulgar joke. There are quite a few action sequences in this film that really paid off visually. The chase scene in particular was one of the best scenes in the film for me because it combined together all the elements of what made the original 'Deadpool' such a great film. There were however bad action sequences, which I believe the writers intentionally made bad because Deadpool himself stops the film to talk to the audience about how bad they are going to be, to which I can understand to a certain point. At the same time though, it did start to get a little repetitive and lost a ton of the comedic value and towards the end, it was like beating a dead horse--kinda pointless.
Aside from the comedy and action, which were both pretty decent in their own rights, you have a story which is the weakest point in this film and why I saved it for last. I don't want to spoil anything about the story for this film, so I will just say that it seemed rather convoluted because it had too many parts to it. Couple that with some questionable acting from some of the supporting characters in this film and leaves the audience with little to be desired. Some would argue that the story for films such as these are supposed to take a back seat because the gore, language, action and comedy sequences are what makes films like 'Deadpool' and 'Deadpool 2' so great, but I believe this film would be far more successful if the story had been cleaned up and was given more focus.
All in all, 'Deadpool 2' was a pretty decent movie and I recommend anyone who saw the first one and liked it to give the sequel a try. I will say again, and for the last time, this is not a child friendly movie, something to consider if you may be on the fence about taking you kids to see this film with you. In the theater I was in I saw about six children, all of which looked as if they were 6 years old or younger so, for the last time, do NOT take your kids to see this movie.

It is a cliche that a movie will make you laugh and make you cry. This movie will literally do both so dramatically that you will leave the cinema physically exhausted. I find it an indictment on professional reviewers that as of this moment they have given a mere 84% to this movie. The only explanation I can fathom is that they are incapable of appreciating the nuances of this film.
Every 15 seconds there is a hilarious joke yet simultaneously a very deep and poly dimensional story is being told in great detail.
I sincerely hope that this film becomes one of the classics studied by students for decades to come. Let them appreciate Akira Kurosawa alongside this masterpiece. To those who don't appreciate this incredible piece of cinematic mastery I can only assume that you are sadly unable to appreciate brilliance and should return immediately to your previous profession of reviewing chewable suppositories.

Ryan Reynolds is back in the role he was born to play.  Once again he does a terrific job.  He is also helped by a terrific supporting cast as he was in the first movie.  As far as the main story was concerned I could take it or leave it.  There is nothing that particularly stands out about it.  Also, while there are some great pop culture references in the film, I think there are a few that have been used a little too much.  The most overused one is the "Say Anything" reference.  However the parachute jump scene was so brilliant and so rip roaring hysterical that it makes the whole movie worth seeing.  I was laughing so hard I almost fell out of my seat.  My sides hurt for the rest of the movie from laughing so hard at that scene.  One last thing, there is a scene during the credits that ends with Wade/Deadpool saying "You're welcome Canada!".  You can leave after that scene.  There is no post credit sequence.

Deadpool 2 - 4 out of 5 - Deadpool 2 is a superhero film based on the Marvel Comics character Deadpool, distributed by 20th Century Fox. It is the eleventh installment in the X-Men film series and a sequel to the 2016 film Deadpool. The film is directed by David Leitch from a script by Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick, and Ryan Reynolds, with Reynolds starring in the title role alongside Josh Brolin, Morena Baccarin, Julian Dennison, Zazie Beetz, T.J. Miller, Brianna Hildebrand, and Jack Kesy. In the film, Deadpool forms the team X-Force to protect a young mutant from Cable. ( Wikipedia)
This film takes the humor and violence of the first film and improves on them. The jokes in this film were done in what felt like a smarter way and hit with the same outburst of laughter throughout the whole theater which made it even better. There is a lot more action in this film and it doesn't mess with the feel of the film at all. The director threw in a lot of little Easter eggs in this film just like the first film had and eagle eye Deadpool/Marvel Fans will love every single one of them. The raunchiness in this film is turn down quite a bit from the first film and I would feel comfortable watching this film with my mother but it is still not for kids. 
This film is a must see, if you saw the first Deadpool and loved it then you will love this film. I was laughing out loud and enjoying every minute of the film which doesn't happen often at the theaters with me. I recommend seeing this in the theaters such as your local Goodrich Theaters. Taking place after the events of Deadpool (2016) Deadpool 2 builds upon the first movie and brings even more laughs and more action. After a tragic event Wade Wilson/Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) is on a soul search to find himself. After Cable (Josh Brolin) shows up from the future to stop a terrible future from happening it's up to Deadpool, a new ally named Domino (Zazie Beetz) and the X-Men (returning from the first film is Colossus (Stefan Kapicic) & Negasonic Teenage Warhead (Brianna Hildebrand) joined by newcomer Yukio (Shioli Kutsuna). I enjoyed this one quite a bit. I don't think it's as good as the first film, but it's so close! The movie does feature better action sequences in this film and the comedy is full throttle at times here. The movie works so well because Ryan Reynolds just embodies the character of Deadpool. The wise cracking and over the top quips just come so smoothly. Brolin is great as Cable, but I wish we had just a bit more on him. It's hard to explain without ruining the movie, but he's definitely got the cool factor going on for him. Domino is great in the scenes she's in, but ultimately I felt like she was underused. Colossus has a better role in this film, but Negasonic definitely takes a step back which I didn't like because she genuinely seems to be a cool character. The movie has a better plot this time around I will say and it flows pretty well. The movie is great overall still and even though it still falls short in a few categories (CG at times is atrocious) I had a fun time watching this. If you enjoyed the first film you'll definitely like this one.

Deadpool 2 had huge expectations to live up to after it's origin story was a R rated thrill ride, but “Deadpool 2” comes up a little short to it’s expectations. The script, by Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick and Ryan Reynolds, is loaded with winky, fourth-wall-piercing eruptions of meta, the kind of humor that can make even the slow-witted and literal-minded feel devilishly clever. Works for me, I guess. But this sequel to the R-rated, X-Men-adjacent surprise blockbuster of 2016 works maybe a little too hard in the service of a dubious cause. “Deadpool 2,” cracking wise at the expense of nearly every intellectual property in the DC and Marvel universes — and occasionally drawing metaphorical blood to go along with the abundant onscreen gore — uses its self-aware irreverence to perform the kind of brand extension and franchise building it pretends to lampoon. Grief and despair drive Wade first to seek revenge and then to try to prevent two other acts of vengeance from taking place. The first 30-40 minuets of the movie weren’t that entertaining to me, there were a few jokes that made me laugh, but for me the movie got going once Josh Brolin’s Cable showed up and kick some ass. And Zazie Beetz is great as Domino. And there are some fantastic cameos, that definitely draw a laugh and a “wait I know who that is”. For me “Deadpool 2” is a good-enough sequel to the original, but it is definitely not better than the first one. I just wish we could of actually seen X-Force.

The first Deadpool movie was something of a paradigm shift in the colourful comic book movie genre. Of course, we'd had the Punisher, the Blade trilogy and Spawn back in the 90s and 2000s, but Deadpool is one that wears a costume more in line with the child friendly Marvel characters. I appreciated Deadpool for its humour and its free expression. It wasn't afraid to show decapitations or make jokes at the expense of people with disabilities. Believe it or not, this is a good thing if we want true equality. We're all equally as ridiculous in Deadpool's eyes. I enjoyed Deadpool 2 even more than its predecessor. It was just as irreverent, but I laughed more and I felt the feels even more. Yes, there are some moments where we just 'have to go along' with what we're seeing on the movie screen, but Deadpool [the movie] is an entity so meta, that I feel like it knows that it has to tread water at times just to allow the more fantastic and fantastical moments shine brighter. This is a movie that has both heart and bowels in abundance and it doesn't mind scolding the extras for forgetting the Kubler-Ross model.

Segue o mesmo tom do primeiro, os absurdos se intensificam e a metalinguagem também - o que eu adoro. 
Ryan Reynolds continua charmoso e hilário, as adições ao elenco (Zazie Beetz, Josh Brolin e o menino Julian Dennison têm momentos impagáveis); os 'cameos' estão entre as melhores coisas do filme e os efeitos visuais, por vezes toscos, encaixam perfeitamente na proposta.

Não curti o roteiro enquanto narrativa, não entendi a insistência com as minas lésbicas que não tiveram desenvolvimento nem utilidade (gostei mais da Míssil Adolescente Megassônico no primeiro filme, inclusive)... Geralmente eu cago para essas coisas de coesão narrativa nesse tipo de filme, mas aqui os desvios que o roteiro tomava, realmente atrapalharam um pouco a minha experiência.

Mas curti. ^^

"Deadpool 2" boldly brandishes its R-rating for hysterical whimsy and stylish ultra-violence as its badge of honor.  Sans gratuitous nudity or sex.  Whatever brazen adult humor should land well beyond most teens.  Hopefully most.  One of the serious grownup themes is child abuse.  That is done with surprising heart, in keeping with the theme of created family.
Ryan Reynolds is amazing as Deadpool/ Wade Wilson.  Still smarter and funnier than thou, this time Ryan's Deadpool exposes his humanity, his true self.  That elevates the movie.  Josh Brolin as cyborg from the future Cable is Ryan's powerful foil.  Cable's dour mission to erase his future tragedy balances in surprising poignancy.  Director David Leitch has the masterful eye for martial arts execution and stylish carnage.  Thankfully, he has a great gift for on-screen chemistry as well.  
Much like I loved "Guardians 2" more than "Guardians of the Galaxy", "Deadpool 2" displays more heart than "Deadpool" despite its iconoclastic banter and irreverence.  It's Old School:  Hero uses his or her powers for good, for family.  Hero fights for love.  To the point:  Deadpool 2 is awesome.

"Deadpool 2" is a sequel that aims for bigger and better and somehow succeeds. The merc with a mouth returns in a film that is funnier, sadder, more action packed, more violent, more character driven and contains even more references to the X-men world, than the first installment. Wade and Vanessa are about to move their relationship forward but a series of unfortunate events leads Wade to prison, were he has to protect a mutant kid from a time travelling soldier that wants to kill him. To succeed in his mission, Wade creates a group of supers, called the X-force. Reynolds manages to top his performance from the first film, adding a lot more depth to Wade, but also making him even more funny and badass. From the new cast of characters, Zazie Beetz is lovely as Domino and Josh Brolin, following his groundbreaking performance as Thanos in another Marvel movie, gives life to the complex Cable in the best way possible. The action is much bigger and better than the first film, with an increased budget that director David Leitch makes a perfect use of. As nearly perfect as the first film was, this sequel somehow manages to improve on it on almost every level. It might not make the best use out of some of its supporting characters, but that's not a major issue. The film has a very smart and unusual - for this genre, at least - perception of evil, that was quite surprising. "Deadpool 2" is a family film that isn't for families, which will make you excited for "X-force", "Brown Panther" and any other film in the franchise that's about to come.

Go see this movie!

Deadpool 2 manages to improve upon its predecessor whilst maintaining the same level of laughs, references, fourth-wall breaking, and action that made the first movie such a breath of fresh air. 
It has been said many times, but I'll say it again anyway, Ryan Reynolds was born to play Deadpool/Wade Wilson; he just seems to get the character. In the role, Reynolds is hilarious and doesn't have a care in the world. He goes back and forth between talking to the audience and the characters in the film with ease. You can have no shame when playing the role of Deadpool and Reynolds completely understands this. He shows the necessary level of energy every step of the way and never lets up on the gas. Similar to Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man, Reynolds fits Deadpool like a glove. Part 2 of Josh Brolin's amazing summer box office run (Pt. 1 being Thanos in Infinity War) picks up with the role of Cable, who is sort of, but not really, the villain. Cable is a big, cyborg mercenary dude who is on a mission that conflicts with Wilson's epiphany-lead undertaking; this leads to a couple exciting action sequences between the two. Brolin doesn't show much humanity at first, but slowly reveals it as the film progresses. Cable is a fun character to watch fight and Brolin successfully establishes his character as the tough-as-nails, detached emotion variety, but more could have been done with the character. A surprising stand-out, Zazie Beetz who plays Domino, made quite the first impression and looks to be a strong addition to the already strong collection of supporting characters. 
Perhaps the biggest flaw of the first Deadpool was its lack of story. It showed Deadpool's origin followed by the pursuit of the man who made him look like an "avocado had sex with an older, more disgusting avocado." Deadpool 2 succeeds in finding a story to go with everything that made the first movie great. In the sequel, Deadpool has to protect Russell, a kid mutant who is being hunted by Cable, and learn things along the way. Themes of love, family, purpose, abuse, friendship, and choice run throughout the movie; the movie felt less like a series of gags building to a climax, and more like a well-rounded story. 
The comedic nature of the Deadpool films are what make them special, and Deadpool 2 is easily the funniest movie I have seen so far this year. The jokes are always present and rarely miss. I would say Deadpool 2 is as funny as the first movie. The action is explosive and uncompromisingly brutal; it also is as violent as the first movie. Once again, the soundtrack choices are interesting as songs are played over scenes you'd never think they'd be used for, lending to the unserious tone. Most remarkably, Deadpool 2 does not end up like many other sequels to smash-hits where the original is made out of a unique formula and succeeds due to its freshness, but when the sequel comes around, the film feels slightly more forced and less fresh. Deadpool 2 stays away from this, improving upon the original even if just slightly. It did not feel forced in the least and its antithesis to other superhero films is appreciated. My only critiques of the film are minor, the end gag dragged on a little too long, the kid was a little annoying at times, and many of the references are likely to be lost in time due to their contemporary nature. 
Deadpool 2 is a film you should see today and is something rarely seen in sequels, an improvement on the original.
