Action-packed and gut-busting hilarious, Deadpool 2 builds further on the success of its predecessor, bringing more gore, plenty of knee-slapping laughs and another terrific and hilarious performance from Ryan Reynolds.

The Movie was really enjoyable. Much more fun as in the first movie. The Jokes are better and other than in the first movie, there is a story which you can comprehend.

The acting was really well done, of course Ryan Reynolds made a great Deadpool and Josh Brolin is obviously very good in playing movie-villains since he plays Cable as well as Thanos. Zazie Beetz really surprised me as Domino, she did a very good job portraying that iconic Character.

And a extra point for Fans of the X-Men Universe was the cameo by some of the X-Men, such as Professor X, Cyclops and Quicksilver, as well as a cameo from Brad Pitt.

I also enjoyed the music quite well and as a summary you could say the Easter eggs and jokes related to the X-Men and MCU movies is what makes the movie so good. The only thing I didn't quite like are the Visual Effects, which looked kind of blurry and plastic. But all in all it was a good movie and fun to watch.

The jokes in this movie hit about 50% of the time but that's really good considering theres at least 100 small jokes in this movie. But all jokes were better than WHAT ARE THOSE from Black Panther so it can slide. 8/10 funny action movie see it

Deadpool 2 follows deadpool's mission to protect a mutant boy Russell a.k.a Firefist (Julian Dennison) from the time travelling mercenary Cable (Josh Brolin).
This movie does everything the original did but takes it up a notch. There's more comedy, more action and more characters than before. Ryan Reynolds is once again excellent as the merc with a mouth. Deadpool is not just about quips and meta jokes all the time but there are even some emotional moments that I really liked.
I loved Cable in this film and Josh Brolin was a great choice for the role. Also just weeks ago Brolin amazed us with his performance as Thanos which is made fun of as we saw in the trailers. One big thing about Deadpool 2 was The X-Force. The trailers almost exclusively promoted the X-Force although after watching the movie I'm in a bit of a pickle. Without spoiling anything I think the direction that they took the X-Force was outrageous and hilarious but also a bit disappointing.
Apart from Deadpool and Cable, other notable characters were Domino (Zazie Beetz), Firefist, Dopinder and this one character I can't spoil. Also Colossus gets a lot to do and his interactions with deadpool are some of the highlights of the film. I quite like Colossus but the previous X-Men films always kept him in the background which made me very happy when I saw the original deadpool and he is just as fantastic in deadpool 2. That leaves us with the rest of the cast including characters like negasonic teenage warhead (Brianna Hilderbrand), Blind Al(Leslie Uggams), Weasel etc. were entertaining but don't really get much to do. 
Veteran stuntman David Leitch who directed this films has previously worked on John Wick and Atomic Blonde, both films with some exceptional fight sequences. So it was obvious that Deadpool was gonna have great fight scenes and it does deliver but doesn't surpass Leitch's previous work. The music is pretty good and it really works well with the tone of the movie. 
Lastly my one problem with the movie which doesn't really bother me that much but still worth mentioning is this one decision that cable makes at the end that I'm not going to spoil but those who have seen the film will probably know what I'm referring to. 
Deadpool 2 although at times may feel more of the same and has a few other minor problems is an extremely entertaining and hilarious film filled with cameos, easter eggs, references and a lot of graphic violence. I had a blast watching Deadpool 2 and I do like it better than the first one.

DP2 goes bigger than the first in every sense, but also somewhat better. The plot is more convoluted yet way more convincing and focused. The story itself is more thrilling. The pacing is impeccable. The script also gave all the characters a fair share of screen time and importance that will make you thoroughly invested in them, specially the old characters.

In contrast to the original, the villains are very compelling and potent; because their motives are way more plausible, but most importantly more clear.

Deadpool 2 is also more heavier in meta jokes, and that's where "bigger" doesn't necessarily mean "better". Honestly, this movie has more creative and funnier jokes that you'd never believe they could exist, but the element of shock and awe can't be put back into its bottle. The result is a smarter, and quite funny, jokes that don't work as well as the original's.

The action is very good, and that's very frustrating! David Leitch is one of the best action film directors who work today, because he make design action sequences and stunt work that can't be forgotten; some of John Wick and Atomic Blonde's action sequences still stick in my mind. However in this film, Leitch made enjoyable action sequences, but totally forgettable.

What surprised me in this movie is that it has a strong emotional impact that is rare to be in a superhero movie. Some scenes are really touching and emotionally devastating.

All in all, I think Deadpool 2 is a slight improvement upon its predecessor, but it proves again that Ryan Reynolds as Wade WIlson/Deadpool is one of the best superhero casting choices ever along with Hugh Jackman as Logan/Wolverine, and Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark/Iron Man. Also, this mid-credits scene is simply the best and coolest mid-credits scene ever put to film!

Okay, not gonna lie, as much as I loved the first one, and was hyped for this, I thought Deadpool was gonna turn out to be one of those films that started great, but the sequels killed it. Very pleased to say, I was not disappointed in the film at all, in-fact it may even be better then the first film. 
 The sequel still has the same tongue-and-cheek humor and over-the-top gory action of the first film. But surprisingly, it also has a lot of emotional moments as well, of which all of the actors did a fantastic job with their roles. Namely Reynolds' as Deadpool (No one will ever be a better fit to play Wade Wilson/Deadpool then Ryan Reynolds he was born for this character) Josh Brolin as Cable, Zazie Beetz as Domino, and young Julian Dennison as Russel/Firefist. 
 One aspect that was really cool (This is a vague spoiler), is that of all the main characters, the film had no true villain. Everyone was just trying to do what they felt was right. 
 Ultimately if you liked the first film, you'll like this one too.

As the 11th installment of the X-Men Cinematic Universe, the first sequel of ‘Deadpool’ exceeds expectations in every way. Before this film was released, I was nervous about how the jokes would turn out from the merc with the mouth; in other words, nervous if the jokes were remained similar to its predecessor. But, they weren’t. They were a lot more hilarious than the first film. Ryan Reynolds brought us a slight dramatic and more charming as Wade Wilson/Deadpool. Bringing us the great team X-Force to the mix was absolutely HILARIOUS. Zazie Beetz shines as Neena Thurman/Domino because of her charm of LUCK. Josh Brolin was great as another comic book character after Marvel’s ‘Avengers: Infinity War’. After Tim Miller’s departure on directing this film, I didn’t know how David Leitch’s style would change this movie, but still remains as a ‘Deadpool’ movie. The film’s soundtrack had great song choices; Tyler Bates’ score is also great, but a few tracks with the choir had me chuckling a bit. This film is a lot more violent and gore than its predecessor, but not as violent as ‘Logan’. There were so many cultural references including the Marvel Cinematic Universe, DC Comics, the studio, and of course, the previous X-Men Cinematic Universe films. 8.3/10.

(91/100)
SPOILERS AHEAD!!! Deadpool 2 is bigger and better, Cable (Josh Brolin) is a very compelling villain/anti-hero. His story is understandable and him joining Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) in the end just makes you feel warm inside. Killing of most of the X-Force in the beginning was hilarious. I also loved the cameo by the X-Men and that they returned Juggernaut (in a good way). Some of the CGI looked a little bit off but the story was compelling enough to take you away from that. 4th wall breaking is back and it's better: Poking fun at Thanos, DC and Green Lantern. When Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) goes back in time to undo some of the things it was just... SO FUNNY!

With a bigger cast, bigger budget, and bigger shoes to fill, does it live up to the hype? YES. JUST YES. Deadpool 2 delivers everything you want from a Deadpool film, and more- comedy, action, and- this time around- a lot more heart. 10/10! Must-see film!

I never thought there would ever be one Deadpool movie, let alone two. The first was a piece of utter brilliance made on a shoestring budget (comparatively) that blew up a lot of convention with its success.

This gave way to the sequel we have before us. The ability was now given to do Deadpool without unnecessary budget constraints. Would the change of directors matter? Short answer, no. Long answer noooooooooooooooooooo. David Leitch steps in and earns his opening sequence credit mention (you'll see), and throws us a Deadpool that is another epic romp of hilarity and action.

As before, the soundtrack is a great co-star to the movie, giving lift to the moments where Ryan Reynolds' DP is at his funniest or his deepest. And DP does have to find some depth within himself as he moves through the film in order to carry it forward.


Some observations:

Every scene with Blind Al is brilliant. The interactions between her and Deadpool are hilarious, and there's a scene further on with the two of them that may leave you in need of a paper bag from all the hyperventilating you'll be doing on account of laughing so hard.

Josh Brolin gets Cable down perfectly, and this guy does not get nearly enough credit for his skill as an actor. Not everyone could make Thanos likable and Cable awesome within the same month, but he has done it.

Zazie Beetz is your show-stealer. She makes a great Domino, and her rapport with Reynolds is obvious.

Peter! X-Force!

It’s about on par with the first film, and it’s hijinks makes it better than most comic book films—they take themselves too seriously. However, it’s still far from ever being considered a classic. Really, I think in 20 years we’ll look back and shake our heads at how the comic book genre got out of hand. The Avengers, X-Men, and DC films need to die off. “Dark Knight” was the apex of the genre and should have spelled the beginning of the end.

Back in 2016, the first "Deadpool" was a true breath of fresh air for the superhero genre. This sequel delivers the same nonstop laughs, explosive action, and just pure fun the first one did. This time around the movie has a heartfelt center and that really makes you care. The movie is just such a blast to experience and all of the characters, new or old, are super entertaining. Despite having a different director, the movie still has the same look and feel as the first while simultaneously telling a whole new story. Ryan Reynolds is lovable as the title role and Josh Brolin's Cable is a nice entry for the franchise and a fairly complex and interesting villain. Fans of the first movie will adore this movie. I truly cannot think of a moment in this movie where I wasn't either laughing out loud consistently or just savoring the sensational action scenes.

Remember California Adventure's former musical spectacular "Aladdin", and how the Genie actor performed freely with humorous timely jokes? Well he's a spirit animal, or a prior example, behind the Deadpool character in relation to the superhero genre since 2016 from poking fun at "Batman v Superman" to co-star Josh Brolin's other Marvel character in the sequel's self-parodic humor. Knowing it was during the post-production phase when James Cameron remarked about the superhero fatigue, I couldn't help but ponder if the film actually went with that fatigue. Never a superhero film ever felt tiresome enough to make your eye lids heavy for a couple of minutes, resulting in losing track of the journey before the predictable destination in one little middle portion.

"Deadpool 2" follows the regular ingredient of a sequel in adding another weight of emotional attachments and obstacles onto the character, who by the way must deal with loss and the meaning of family including what it takes to be part of a team. The official, more serious given synopsis, by note, is Wade Wilson, aka Deadpool, decides to put together his own team of similar-natured mutants to protect a young mutant from being hunted by the angered time-traveling cyborg Cable. But that's only telling less than half of the direction since the character himself is truly a wild card of the Marvel brand.

Well, the superhero comedy is surprisingly less inappropriate while it still is along with clever, parodic humor when subtle, but it's actually tiresome and occasionally annoying to make it solidly decent at a surprising low rating since the "Fantastic Four" reboot (*insert Deadpool gasping*) - although still offers more entertainment value at a B level. As a responsive consideration, additionally referring back to the wild card remark, this is probably the most unique of the genre's modern turn by being a self-parody that still causes groans like any feature-length parodies but the amount of laughs overall, either to the parodic jokes or not, unbalanced the scale to its favor. Because of that style, it's one of two factors that departs from the "X-Men" franchise's thematic taste that even the predecessor possesses, but it's understandable if Deadpool wants to be his own franchise by distancing from the parenthood.

Adjacent to its relation to the overall franchise, what's also a departure is adding another element to the grown narrative through Josh Brolin's character Cable, who literally shifted the franchise's time-space continuum with a recognizable connection of an experienced, still-superior narrative. Ryan Reynolds may have had the spotlight from before and was given an enlarged role to the film, both creatively behind and in front of the camera, with a pleasantly-given stakeholding human drama and still fun as ever with comedic energy, as the the film's main soul, it was Brolin who again stole the spotlight from the titular character - singular this time - by introducing a more freshly compelling character who hasn't been introduced cinematically. Another scene-stealer who stole the spotlight ahead of Reynolds is Zazie Beetz as the lucky mercenary Domino with a charismatic performance that's fresher than Reynolds'.

Behind the keyword "fresh", the meaning is referring to the film's dimmed freshness from its more preferable predecessor. The sequel stumbled through the parody genre, in an occasionally over-constipated attempt of being funnier but failed to instead become annoying, and the aforementioned departure in tonal narrative differences. The main aspects that were relied on as persuaded main attractions through the generic taste of action and energetic comedy by Reynolds' charm, and the former of the three increased surrounding the cause-and-effect mayhem from Cable is proof of the original freshness. The rest worked with some struggling to only find decreased acceptance. This isn't because of change of direction from Tim Miller to David Leitch ("Atomic Blonde"), it's a plain aura and notion that sequels doesn't meet up to the original. Speaking of direction, complimenting Leitch's direction is rather difficult when there's a sense of convolution on the overall craftsmanship between his or Reynolds's expanded creativity that is more under cynicism. (Reynolds probably proud of himself to have this film to be luckily seen the second time to find this out another day).

After experiencing the sort-of overhyped "Deadpool 2" that was funnier through the marketing campaign that promised to be as funny as the first coming, the character has lost a viewer into unsure skepticism towards the likelihood of seeing another Deadpool-centered film in the theaters, being a definite maybe for a fitting price of a free or discounted ticket instead of a full-priced ticket. It may be a resulted worthwhile addition with the expected qualities that made the original entertaining in a slight decrease of presentation, but it also strays and bores away from the expectations. (B)

Deadpool 2 - Review (2018)

The Good
Ryan Reynolds once again was born to play as Wade Wilson / Deadpool, but this time as a proper sequel should always do develops the character and shows Deadpool actually grow as a character.

Josh Brolin as Cable, he is perfect as the character that definitely shows more depth than I thought they would do and Brolin's plays the perfect straight man to Reynolds wacky character. Josh Brolin's physical performance is badass too (its definitely the year of Brolin with Thanos and Cable 

Zazie Beetz as Domino is perfect I love her on Atlanta andi love her in this movie, she's a badass with her powers and she has good back and forth with Deadpool

David Lietch's Direction is what I was worried about with Story, but he definitely proves that he should stay and the one thing he does do that improves from first film is a the action, the action is phenomenal. 

Negasonic Teenage Warhead, Vanessa and Colossus are all good.

Its more Meta than the first film

The X-Force Team Up Sequence is Genius and with a Amazing Song with the Sequence. 

There's another great Highway Chase scene

Even though there are some familiar beats, it is very much different from the first film 

While I like the villain's from the first film, the people fighting Deadpool in this (including Cable) are bigger threats especially not really spoiler anymore the Juggernaut is badass (even though he is a big CGI thing and it could of been touched up a bit), but having them makes the sequel Bigger and Darker.

The Cameos are fucking amazing 

The emotional Beats definitely work.

The Bad
TJ Miller could of been like cut or killed off somehow, his jokes in this one are forced as hell and he does absolutely nothing, they could of cut him even after his accusations and his arrest for a fake bomb threat.

While the ending is great the thing without spoiling what Cable does especially having his motivation clear the moment you see him instantly changes for no reason really, especially when someone has a certain thing (you will see what I'm talking about).

Overall: Deadpool 2 is a blast, and while it does improve certain things from the first film, but I think the First Deadpool is still a little better, by being a smaller simple film which is basically a love story while this was a family film.

Overall Grade: A-

It’s bigger and better! Come young and old, not for the size of Deadpool 2’s budget but for how the film uses it to rewrite history (Green Lantern’s and Marvel’s history that is). Deadpool 2 delivers an extraordinarily witty and outrageous film which bends the limits of fourth wall breaks to their will. Deadpool 2 builds upon the first film in new and immature ways that are unpredictable and hilarious. Ryan Reynolds opens this film with an explosive beginning (literally) and concludes it on a sweet note on family. Although the movie focuses majorly on a love letter to what Deadpool can do in an R-rated superhero flic. The film dodges many pit-falls of sequels and becomes another Empire Strikes Back. The blood and gore, the humor, the cameos, action scenes, CGI characters and excellent new and old characters in the movie, all create a Deadpool film for the ages.

Deadpool 2 delivers more than enough thrills and genuine laughs thanks to another great performance by Ryan Reynolds to win you over. 
The real trick Deadpool 2 pulls off is that it's more touching then the first film, something Hollywood sequels struggle to pull off. As Deadpool puts it" Deadpool 2 is a family film." Well that may be a stretch but I guess you could say it's more family then the first. 
As Deadpool teams up with his hilarious new counterparts you can't help but feel your in for a good time. New additions like Domino, who has some really clever and funny lines, Shatter Star, who offers physical humor (If you've seen the movie you'll know what I am talking about), Bedlam, once again more physical humor. As well as Bedlam and Vanisher, who offers a hilarious suprise cameo with Brad Pitt, and last but not least Peter who frankly has no powers and doesnt  last long. And who could forget the "villian" Cable who is played by Josh Brolin who hits it big with his second superhero film of the year.
Brolin makes an effective Cable, even if lacking Reynolds witty remarks and quick humor as Deadpool and seeing them later team up in the film along with some familiar X-men is delicious.
Deadpool 2 is an impressive entry in the carrer of director David Lietch, with this being only his second major motion picture, the first being Atomic Blonde(2017) and after those to films he's off to a happy start.
In the end Deadpool 2 brings together hero and anti-hero for a greater cause. Throwing everything it has to offer at you Deadpool 2 will leave fans grinning with the characters having more growing to do this time around. The makeup of heros we see known as X-force should have plenty of more hilarious and brutally funny adventures together.

The first Deadpool movie is just a tiny bit better than this one, but this movie was pretty good. The acting by most of the cast was good, The directing by David Leitch was pretty good. The humor was a huge improvement over the first one, the humor was hilarious and I could not stop laughing. The action sequences were mostly good, but my only problem is that during the last battle sequences there was a bit too much shacky cam, but the are still action sequences are still great, exciting, and badass, but the shacky cam was just not the best. The ending could have been better than it was. The post credits scene was one of the best parts about this movie, it was just really really good. But afterwards, Deadpool 2 is still an hilarious, action packed R-rated movie that people should go see.

Deadpool 2 is everything you loved about the first movie and more!! I have been a Deadpool fan long before the movies. and neither movie disappoints. The sequel has a different feel to it. This is obviously due to the higher budget. it is funny and action packed. The writing is impeccable, and it is brilliantly scored. It not only exceeds expectations; it shatters them. For a sequel in an era that is filled with sequels, reboots. and remakes it doesn't coast off of the inertia of its predecessor, or just fall flat, like most. It is its own movie, and it's a damn good one! 10/10
